text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

In a region pulsating with
innovation and opportunity,

we embarked on a
journey to hear directly

from the visionaries
shaping Latin America's

economic and societal landscape,
each offering unique insights

into the critical
role of business

in fostering economic
mobility and equity.
[MUSIC PLAYING]
[MUSIC PLAYING]
So I'm Gaston Bottazzini.

I've been the CEO of Falabella
for the last five years.

I was born in Argentina,
but have been living
in Chile for the last 15 years.

Just to give you some
background on Falabella,

it's a very old
company, 135 years old.

We operate in retail
through several formats

in financial services, mostly
through personal banking

and in commercial real estate,
through shopping malls.

We operate in seven
countries in the region.

Our main countries are
Chile, Peru, and Colombia,

but we also have
operations in Mexico,

which is our newest
operation, also

in Brazil, Uruguay,
and Argentina.

So we want to talk about
the role of business

in addressing
economic inequality.

So we'd love to know the
role that your company plays

in addressing
economic inequality.

Please give us a
high level overview.

So for us, it's extremely
important as a company,

and we have increasingly
taken action

around how to be more inclusive,
how to fight inequality.

And we do it in three fronts,
the customer, our team,

and the communities
in which we operate.

The customer, in my opinion,
is the most important front,

because it's really what you
do and how you present yourself
as a company to the public.

And given how diverse
we are, the way we

address that is very
different by business.

But, for example, and
just to give you some

examples, in
financial services, we

are probably one of the
companies in the countries

in which we operate that
has a more proactive

financial inclusion program,
both from the point of view

of giving people products,
but as importantly,

from the point of view of
promoting financial education,

in schools where we collaborate
with financial education

throughout the financial
life of a person.

Interestingly enough,
in our countries,

people graduate, sometimes
even from university,

with very low
financial education.

So giving financial
products to people

without that
background is actually

could be counterproductive
rather than
promote financial inclusion.

In retail, I think--
just to give an example,

in the last few
years, we have gone

through an overhaul of
the type of clothing

we design in Colombia, for
example, where, we went

from designing clothing
for a stereotyped body

to really learning what the
different Colombian personas

look like and like to dress
like and, therefore, change,

in the back, how
we design clothing.

So that's an example, I
think, that is very important,

that companies have to
adapt to the consumers

and, in particular, not
only in terms of design,

but also in terms of
the cost of the product

so that consumers
can actually afford,

from a very early stage,
different products.

In our home
improvement business,

for example, we work
a lot with reskilling,

because that's a business
that lends itself
very much for reskilling.

And therefore, that's
the main focus.

When we turn towards
our own team,

I think that's a very big
challenge in Latin America.

We're a 100,000 person team
with all kinds of backgrounds
and socioeconomic levels.

And I think one of the
challenges we face, for example,
is reskilling.

How do we manage
the fact that we

are, as companies, transforming
the skills necessary to change?

And you want to go
through that process

without necessarily changing the
team, but having the team adapt.

And as a result of
that, we have taken

on a lot of reskilling
initiatives.

And I think the challenge there
is how you make them scale.

It's easy to find
a group of people

that can turn from
call center operators

to, for example, working
on UX issues on a web page.

But how do you take
that to the level

where you actually help
a large number of people
go through that process?

That's probably the
main challenge we face.

And then, in terms
of the communities,

how do you translate what you do
with your customer to the impact

you have in the
community at large?
I

Think one example
there is how we

work with prisons
in home improvement,
where our team from Sodimac--

and it's mostly done
through volunteering--

will go to prisons
and teach skills that

have to do with home
improvement, which helps people

that will have a very tough
time reinserting in society

in general go
through that process

more easily because they're
building some skills.

And at the same time, they're
getting some additional income

in the short term for
their families, et cetera.
That's amazing.

Can we go back to reskilling
a little bit more?

Can you give us a couple
of examples, maybe

some color around
what type of impact

you're having and maybe a couple
of examples of how people are
progressing in their careers?
Right.

So I think the basic issue that
we face, which I prompted to,

is the fact that our company, as
most companies around the world,

are transforming
and are migrating

from a more physical
world to a hybrid world.

In our case, our physical world
remains extremely important,

but we also have a very
strong digital world

that is the one that
is growing the most.

And as that happens,
many of the jobs

that you have in the physical
world become obsolete.

And we, for example, have
very large call centers.

We have a lot of
cashiers, which,

if you go to a supermarket
or to a department store,

you'll see most of
the cashiers are being
replaced by self-checkouts.

All of those jobs
are disappearing,

and the jobs that are
coming into the market
are more skilled labor jobs.

So there is a problem
of growing unemployment

with more unskilled labor and
shortages in more skilled labor.

So what we have to do
as a response to that

is try to help our own
people, and sometimes even

people outside the company,
to build some of these skills.

And we have a lot of examples
of partnering, for example,

with either non-for-profit
organizations or some

of the staff
augmentation companies

that do development or do
UX to help devise programs

that our people will
join and, therefore, be

able to move internally
to other jobs

or move to other
jobs in other places.

And we have been
successful in doing that.

But as I said
before, the problem

is the numbers, because
the numbers are very large.

And it's relatively easy
to take 10, 20, 30 people

and build skills and find
another role in the company.

It's harder to do that
with thousands of people,

and that's probably
the challenge we face.
OK.
Thank you.

So if one of your
peers said, what

is the single most important
initiative that you

are taking to address
economic inequality,
what would you say that is?
Would it be reskilling?
Would it be something else?

I think given the
size of our company

and the number of
customers we serve--

we serve, yearly, about 38
million customers in the region.

So anything we do with our
customers in terms of inclusion,

in terms of fighting
inequality, is always
going to be the highest impact.
So even small decisions--

And I think this is not
only about initiatives,

but it's also about
becoming conscious

that many of the decisions
that you take day

to day in the company, that you
make day to day in the company,

have an impact on
economic inclusion,
have an impact on inequality.

So when you make the
decision of whether you're

going to distribute only
to those places that

are economically
viable versus, you're

going to subsidize distribution
to a place where it's probably

not as economically
viable, that's

an economic inclusion and an
equality kind of decision.

When you decide how
you're going to hire,

whether you're going to put a
very heavy weight on credentials

versus try to make
your hiring process

as credential blind as possible,
that also has a very big impact.

But again, I think we
make decisions vis-a-vis
our clients every day.

And if you have a
team that is conscious

that those decisions not
only have an economic impact,

but they also have
an impact on society

and are able to
prioritize that correctly,

that's probably
the most important.

Is this good for business
at a very high level?

Well, I think it depends
on how business people look

at the equation, because
many of these things

are not good for business
in the sense of being

profitable in the short
term, and you need
to be ready to sacrifice that.

I think there is a little
bit of a fallacy of thinking

that economic inclusion
and fighting inequality
is very good for business.

And there's always initiatives
that are good for business,
but you have to go beyond that.

And I think if you
take the perspective

that what you're building
is long-term value rather

than short-term
economic results,

then you're building a lot more
customer loyalty over time.

You are building a
team that has a lot--

that has a higher
purpose and, therefore,

will have more commitment and
will be willing to go further,

probably lower employee
turnover as well.

So if you look at
those indicators of how

you are building
longer term equity,

I think it's very
good for business.

Tackling an economic
inequality is very hard work.

So what would be your
piece of advice for someone

who wants to make a
difference and really
isn't sure how to proceed?

I would say my
piece of advice is
to take a two-pronged approach.

Devise initiatives
that you think

will have the highest
impact, whether it

is on customers,
your team, community,

but work very hard
on the culture
and the decision-making culture.

And that will probably
have more impact over time.

Probably, you will not
be able to highlight

a single initiative,
but you will have impact

across all of these
fronts over time,

given the day-to-day
decisions that you're making.

And because we're
Harvard Business School,

we are curious,
what do you think

that the role of
business education

is right now for this
issue specifically?

Well, I think, in
general, we need

business leaders to be more
conscious of the impact
of their decisions.

And I think particularly
in the last few years,

there has been an
erosion of the trust

between business leaders,
communications leaders,
and government.

And the only way
to repair that is

that business leaders start
thinking more consciously

about the impact
of their decisions

and how they interact with
all of these stakeholders

so that they start
to build trust again.
OK.

And the role of
business schools?

I think business schools
are the ones that

are shaping how these business
leaders think and, therefore,

have a very important
role, I think,

in particular, the initiative
that Harvard Business School

is taking right now about really
highlighting the importance
of inclusion and inequality.

It is, no doubt, a
very important role.

In 2024 and beyond,
the next couple

of years, what trends
or challenges would you

think other business
leaders should think--

should contemplate
for this issue?
Yes.

I think there's a context
today in the region, also,

of a macroeconomic context
of higher inflation,

of lower growth in
many of the countries.

And I think businesses
are going to be pressured.

Our business is pressured
for short-term results.

So I think there's
going to be an increased

level of consciousness necessary
in how people make decisions

about how you adapt to these
different contexts, variables,

and, at the same time, keep
inclusion and inequality
at the forefront.
